Name: The Future of the Mind: The Scientific Quest to Understand, Enhance, and Empower the Mind

ReviewList.Text: Whoa!  What a book to read if you want a glimpse of where science is taking us in the future!  This highly interesting read does a great job of explaining current and future possiblities of tracking, improving and studying the human brain.  From current research of creating prosthetics which can be controlled from thought to 'helmet' scanners which can read your thoughts to portable body scanners like "Doc" from Star Trek used - the future possibilities are amazing.  There is so much work being done in creating ways to actually read one's mind - which would be of enormous benefit for some people stricken with disease...to implants in the brain to stimulate thought, movement, recovery from stroke or traumatic brain injury.  The book lightly touches on the downside of such technology - could police use some of these devices which are currently in development to read your mind? could the government?  What are the ethical implications of this technology?  How could it be controlled once it's on the open market?  The author did a great job of presenting the information in an easy to read, understandable format - I almost read the book in one sitting the concepts were so interesting.  The book touches on the amount of research being done by private companies as well as DARPA, and it left me feeling that  futuristic science fiction movie plots aren't really that far away from becomming a  reality.

This is my first reading from this author and was expecting much more because I really enjoy him whenever I see him on the screen. However, this book I thought had a whole lot of 'fill' in it and really didn't seem to address the title of the book. Rather boring reading, nothing really exciting new stuff in the making, just seemed to fill pages with 'stuff'.

Skip this book if you are a psychologist or have a background or training in cognitive science or the study of consciousness. The book will frustrate you, because Kaku gets his facts wrong so often--which is surprising given that Kaku is a scientist. For example, his theory of consciousness is not a theory of consciousness at all. It is sort of a theory of one kind of mental function, but certainly not a theory that has any chance of explaining why we need to have subjective experience (qualia). One could easily argue that Kaku's concept of consciousness, which centers on the mental function of making mental models of the future, could conceivably have nothing to do with conscious experience, since it may well be possible to create such models unconsciously. By the way, Kaku uses the term "subconscious" instead of "unconscious," a term that carries its own misleading implications. And Kaku completely misconstrues David Chalmers' "hard problem," among many other errors. Finally, Kaku tends to go on and on with long passages in which he ruminates about issues that he imagines might come up in the future, such as which children robots should be programmed to rescue in a disaster. With all that said, however, if you don't know anything about theories of consciousness or cognitive science, you might enjoy the book.

If you haven't read Michio Kaku before, you are missing out.  He is one of the most compelling writers and commentators on the world of science and coming innovations.  The future of the mind explores the amazing developments in neuroscience and the future possibilities with the "gee whiz" enthusiasm of a kid in a science museum.  Great reading.

If this is your first book on mind and brain, you may enjoy. But having read intense books from Dr. VS Ramachandran and others on mind and consciousness, this book by Dr Kaku was a disappointment. It is a hodgepodge of quotes from various books. What irritated me the most of reference to all sci-fi movies in every page. Liked aspects of categorizing animal and plant kingdom by levels of consciousness, but beyond that you will read quotes from many pchycologists, neurosurgeons, references to movies like avatar and matrix, open questions about religion and god.....for an average reader, you've already heard it all and seen it all!!!

I'm a little disappointed after reading Michio Kaku's book "The future of the mind". I'm clear that curiosity moved myself to do it, because others books I've previously read from him that I feel satisfied after complete the reading. However, the issues presented in the book are shallow, and the theory about consciousness is very questionable. Maybe someone could say that is a divulgation book, but anyway in my opinion it is half way. I hope that Micho Kaku will go back to write about Physics that is his core subject.

Kind of interesting, but really just a bunch of disjointed, somewhat repetitious speculation about things that might or might not happen in the future.  A somewhat more analytical (and a little bit more skeptical) approach would have been much more interesting, because it would have let the reader actually think about the likelihood of some of these things happening.  Plus, the author seems hopelessly naive about the ability of our politics and government to control some of the rather frightening scenarios envisioned.

I am an average person, and ordinarily I would be intimidated by the subject and the author. But I went to hear Dr. Kaku speak recently, and his lecture was stunning in the breadth of ideas (and he's an entertaining guy). So I bought his book as soon as it came out, and I have not been disappointed. He writes in a manner that is easily understood even by those of us who are not scientists. The current brain research being done is amazing in scope, and the hope that ways to fix brain illnesses or irregularities, which affect all of us in some way, will  be found. Startling fact: half of our population over 80 will develop Alzheimer's, a human catastrophe that is slowly unfolding. Then there's Parkinson's, ADHD, depression, autism, and on and on. What scientific research could be more important to the fate of mankind than knowing more about our brains? But the book is about much more than just what's happening now. As the title implies, it's about the future and what is/is not possible. I loved it and intend to read some of the chapters again. I really enjoy a book that opens my mind to other possibilities.

Well informed cognitive scientists recognize that they have no consensual definition of consciousness, that they can't measure the presence of consciousness scientifically, and that the nature of mind-brain correlations remains a mystery. But the author of this book, who has no qualifications as a cognitive scientist, brushes all those concerns aside and simply declares, as if with papal infallibility, that the mind is nothing more than what the brain does. His assertion is treated as a self-evident fact, so no empirical evidence or compelling reasoning is offered in support of this hypothesis. A scientific hypnosis, unlike a philosophical theory or religious belief, must lend itself to empirical validation or refutation, but this reductionist hypothesis does not. Nevertheless, Kaku presents it as a scientific fact. This is pseudoscience at its worst.  As the historian Daniel Boorstin pointed out, the greatest obstacle to discovery is not ignorance, but the illusion of knowledge. By presenting the illusion of knowledge that the nature of consciousness and it's role in nature is already known scientifically, Kaku obstructs open-minded inquiry into this aspect of reality that has so far eluded scientific discovery.

A Physicist’s take on the human mind, and where the latest science is and future possibilities on consciousness, the possibilities of telepathy, the possibility of telekinesis or just moving things by using your minds.  A chapter on the possibility of implanted memories.  A chapter on talk of enhancing human intelligence, so that we can all be as smart as Einstein.  A chapter on dreams, and creating dreams and thoughts.  The latest on mind control and altered states of consciousness.  Where computer scientists are on with artificial intelligence, and then chapters on existence as just energy and possible alien minds.  Overall a fascinating summary of all things in modern science relating to the human mind.  While I realize most of the information is probably gathered by researchers Dr. Kaku provides his take on all of the subject and brings in his own projections for what is possible for the human mind and civilization as a whole.  Just a fascinating book with tons of information, but still an easy read for the lay person.  Highly recommended, if you have a question feel free to leave a comment below and I will try to answer it.

An amazing book from an amazing mind. Kaku often presents complex issues in a way that is easy t understand (but he does expect you to have a rudimentary understanding of the world around you). In this book, Kaku goes beyond physics and explores the human mind with the same style, grace, and presentation that flows throughout all his works. if you are a fan or familiar with Kaku, you are sure to be enthralled by his latest book. Kaku is more than a teacher, he is a guide down a mysterious path that only brings us better understanding of our true selfs and our place in the universe.

I liked everyone of his other books (though even then must say he was out of his comfort zone when speaking of socio economic topics).  With this one though it made me think here is a guy that is extremely smart and well spoken on some topics (technology, cosmology) but left me really wondering on others.  The first was with the definition of consciousness.  Kaku summarizes  consciousness as the ability to perceive the outside world and formulate models of it into the future.  The first few times he uses this definition I thought he may be planning to expand on it but instead he repeats endlessly.  To casually make this assessment on what is a topic that could take up several books was bothersome to say the least.  To add to this he talks of advancements to the mind only in terms of our current socio economic predicaments.  For instance he speaks of  a sort of telepathy that could be used on the battlefield overlooking that 1)future wars may not have human ground troops 2)if we could have telepathy we may find better ways of solving problems than shooting chunks of metal at eachother.  But more frustrating was the lack of discussion of the spiritual aspect of the human brain.  He talks about how we can be smarter and happier but not nicer (ie less psychotic).  This would be a controversial discussion no doubt and I hear you on the fear of a borg/bravenewworld scenario . Yet still with all the fascination of the brain of Einstein why not some mention of the brain of Ghandi, King, Gotama?  On the one hand you have the supposed techie nerds wanting to build HAL or Lawnmower Man and on the other are the supposed hippie granola types that appear to think humanity would be better off plowing fields and destroying all our gadgets. I have been looking for a book that is not aligned in either camp but sees the value in both.  Other than Ray Kurzweil not much out there.  On a personal note I am more bitter with the neo hippies that dont see the value in adding their voice to the AI/Mind Enhancement topic.  I have been a fan of Mr. Kaku from his other books but was disappointed in his ability to step outside of the technerd box.

Neuroscience research has been exploding and this book will take you to the cutting edge of recent developments. No one explains science to the layman like Dr. Kaku.  He continues his high quality output with this new book which captures your interest immediately and keeps it right to the end. I found it to be a quick read that I did not want to put down. The author takes you on a tour of the brain by starting with the physical, moving to the mind, then consciousness, then leaving the body altogether with speculation of how consciousness may exist independently.  Fascinating treatment of current events, and recommended for everyone who has a brain. Science is moving quickly these days -don't get left behind. Read this book!

Einstein once said: "If a scientist can't explain a new concept in a way that is easily understandable to the average person ... he probably does not understand the concept very well himself." This is the third book I have read by Kaku. As one of the world's leading theoretical physicists it is abundantly clear from his books that the author understands the subjects he writes about extremely well. Reading his books are a joy. The subject of "consciousness" is one I have been extremely interested in and have accordingly read several books on over the last few years. This book is by far, the best I have read on the subject. Fascinating and easy to understand.

I love this book. It's like mind porn. It takes a complex topic and makes it wildly interesting, understandable, and sexy. So much of what we see and believe is based on outdated science. It's time the general public got caught up on what's going on in the labs and pushed to make that reality for all of us. Let's take off the training wheels and blast through limiting beliefs! Even the technologies that are available today are seen as "experimental" and "new age" because of old, crusty, "rational" thinking. More people need to be aware of what is out there. This book provides a way to access that information. Read it!

This book is about more than just the future of the mind.  It's about how the brain works and the research that's going on to now to understand how the brain works.  Once you understand how the brain works, you can work on things to improve your own brain.

First 1/4 of the book is interesting stuff about current research and technology in the study of the mind. The rest seems to be blue sky idle speculation about what might happen. Most is so far out that it is just fantasy. I couldn't even finish it. I was pretty disappointed given how much I have enjoyed some of this TED talks.

I was raving about this book when I first started reading it, but then found it somewhat disappointing. Perhaps my expectations were a bit too high, because I loved Kaku's other books so much. Kaku's books on far-out physics-- superstring theory, wormholes, and other dimensions--are simply extraordinary, but in this new book about the mind, he's not accurately informed about a number of scientific studies in parapsychology, cognitive enhancement, near-death experience research, psychedelic drugs, etc., and simply parrots the mainstream "scientific" opinion, sometimes even getting the facts wrong. Nonetheless, the book is filled with lots of wonderful information about the brain, new technologies, and bold speculation about the future that I really enjoyed reading.

I've always enjoyed the writings of Michio Kaku.  He has the amazing gift of taking his significant understanding of complex topics and translating them into easily digestible language for ordinary human beings.  This book is an ever so slight bend from his usual topics (although not as far from them as I originally thought it might be) by focusing on the mind.  He leverages all of his theoretical physics knowledge, coupled with his extensive conversations with neuroscientists, to put a unique perspective to the potential that lies within each one of us - in "The Future of the Mind."  I highly recommend this book to all who are curious about what the future may hold.

I rate this book highly because it is informative and also easy to relate to. He covers the subject well without using a lot of technical terms. He directs his book for the average person who wants to learn about the mind without going into boring details . This book is directed for the curious without requiring a huge background in neurology. Michio is a great scientist and one of my favorites.  I love his TV shows on the Science Channel.

Interesting material but presented in an elementary and sometimes repetitive manner as a way to get his point across. Anyone reading a book on physics,  for the most part, are going to be a bit more sophisticated and will understand the material or have more familiarity with it. The chapter prognosticating on the future of bionics and the evolution of robots got a bit weary early on.

An easy read and very informative.  Dr. Kaku has a writing style that's easy to follow and explains the subject matter well.  I found his references to science fiction stories refreshing and his futuristic mind set is evident;  Makes me wish I could be in his class.

This book is very enlightening and fascinating! I highly recommend this book to anyone interested in understanding your own mind and/or to better understand what the future of mindful technology holds. : )

Great way to understand the latest in brain research as well as the latest in the laws of physics. Dr Kaku's theory of consciousnesses is very rational and very well explained. Sometimes the ideas on future seem too far fetched but are mostly relevant in the context of what is possible with the current state and direction of the research.

Michio Kaku has done it yet again. His exploration of the scientific advances related to the understanding of the human brain is a fascinating journey. And the implications for the future of humanity are mind boggling. a must read.

I really liked the explanation of how the mind machine works.  The speculation about future technology did occasionally read like science fiction, but was very well grounded in real science and was very plausible.  The idea that we can actually see dreams on a monitor screen seems fantastic, but Kaku explains how it already is happening.

It is an entertaining read, but the conclusions seem superficially cheerful and tidy. It reminds me a bit of the videos from grade school in the 1960s in which atomic energy was portrayed as the wonderful future for solving all our energy problems, our future travel would be by jet-propelled backpacks and machines would cook and serve our food.

I started with Visions, and Hyperspace, and I so appreciated the way Dr. Kaku could bring some serious concepts in science into understandable bites that I could digest.  This book set him a similar task for neuroscience, and I think he has done a good job.  Yes, there is speculation toward the end, but isn't that how all science begins?

Michio Kaku is a specialist in Physics, not mind research. Much of the book is speculation, there is so much going on in this area I would look for something written by a current researcher like the recent article in National Geographic Feb 2014.

This encyclopedic snapshot of a wide range of scientific research relates to just two newly revealed mother lodes of source material: the human brain and outer space. Dr. Michio Kaku, a theoretical physics professor at the City College and City University of New York, describes his boyhood fascination with both subjects and his facility in discussing what would appear to be very distant but some-how related answers to exciting new discoveries that get little mention in the popular press. Bu Kaki and his colleagues have given rise to a plethora of movies and TV series focused on the misuse or outright evil cooked up by the world's bad guys to take advantage of super or telepathic brains, brain networks and intelligent robots. Then Kaku switches over to the vastly more complicated subject of aliens from outer space. Even though we have not yet to find one, Kaku dives in these soon-to-be-charted waters. The professor provides much interesting speculation on the consciousness and intelligence of these creatures who may be trillions of years ahead of us and as interested in us as we are in fruit flies. More than a popularizer, Kaku interviews many of the science protagonists mentioned in his book. And he he seems to know just what questions to ask the not-always-communicative scientists. Definitely worth a read or a listen (14 CDs) to anyone who cares to know what the pointy heads are up to these days. With a strong voice, Feodor Chin, a professional actor, keeps a steady pace, in his reading.

We read this for book club and while I liked some of the information and discussion at the meeting, I found myself skim reading this book because it read like a college textbook.  It was easy to read, just boring.

This work was very well researched and very informative. I would recommend this book for anyone looking to see and understand the milestones being achieved in Neurology. Mind blowing what has been accomplished.

Prof. Kaku hits another one out of the park! It's incalculable the good he's done in kick-starting an interest in science among youth (and maintaining enthusiasm amongst oldsters like yours truly)! Bravo!
I really enjoyed the book at first, but the last third of the book seemed to be just a bunch of wild speculation; speculation based mostly on science, but speculation just the same.
Nothing really new or earth shaking - I kept reading, hoping it would get better.  Editing got especially sloppy during the last quarter of the book.
While reading this, I felt as if Michio Kaku wrote it for children, or to be narrated for a fluffy Leaning Channel documentary.

Kaku's overview of neuroscience at the dawn of the 21st century is an important read for anyone seriously interest in the basic trajectories of research that impact our ideas about intelligence, mental health and identity. This is a well-organized mixture of scientific summary and basic philosophical speculation that help to integrate even the most non-scientific reader into the central problems hovering around neuroscience today. Because Kaku is a physicist, the work displays some surprising cameos from physicists and their perspective on the human mind, though these ultimately benefit the reader without mystifying the work's biological/chemical center of study. Kaku is a very balanced thinking and remains constantly aware of the need for a scientific defense of his claims. I am interested to read his other works: he is exceptionally gifted as a popular science writer, though I admit that he is also shamelessly self promoting.

This mildly entertaining book is so riddled with inaccuracies and misunderstandings that it is worse than useless.  The author relies on his laurels as a Theoretical Physicist to sell what is essentially a piece of really bad scientific journalism on a field with which he is only cursorily familiar.  The writing style and arguments are sophomoric.  Vacuous generalities are offered without substantiation.  He seems to fail to realize that some of his definitions and explanations are circular.  In a number of areas where I am familiar enough with the science to judge, the author proffers statements and explanations that are flat out wrong.  A slightly precocious, well-read humanities undergraduate could have written a better book.
A book that will keep you thinking long after you've finished it...you'll never look at the future quite the same again.

This is a fascinating topic, but it may have been better represented by a neuroscientist than a theoretical physicist.  I have thoroughly enjoyed Kaku's treatment of physical concepts through his other works, as he does an exceptional job of relating complex physical concepts in an accessible manner.  However, I found that The Future of the Mind was a bit incoherent.  Topics seemed to ramble and bleed together without appropriate segues and the author seems to go off on tangents.  For example, the lengthy section on robotics is an interesting topic, but it's correlation to neurology is so loose that it seems like it would've been better treated in a different book altogether.  Kaku does an extensive amount of research. He visits labs and interviews scientists all over the world, but I didn't get a sense that his notes were well organized in the end product.

Michio Kaku has always been a most interesting lecturer and writer, and his current work does not change this opinion. Future of the Mind in some respects reminds me of the early editions of Popular Science magazine, which, when I read them as a young lad, made me want to hurry onto the future for all the wonders to behold. In this case, however, Professor Kaku provides a way to understand what the brain may be able to accomplish through technology, based on somewhat of what is being accomplished today. For we laymen who are not particularly familiar with the brain and the way it operates, Future of the Mind provides some insight into the way this complex, powerful, and magnificent structure works. For those who may believe that someday we will reach the singularity, the book may provide some hope.
Another great book from Kaku who never fails to excite you about the potential of the future!  Loved it!
This should be a must read in schools. The author really knows the working of the brain. It is awesome!

I think a better title might be "The Future and the Mind". In his readable, comprehensive style, Kaku goes somewhat too far with speculation instead of science. It's fine that he has seen so much of the future in sci-fi writing and movies, but linking plot points to "someday we may, it is possible, perhaps they will ..." was too frequently an easy way out of the realm of science fact. In addition, he glosses over many important issues of values and ethics raised by the research and hypotheticals he explores. That said, I found this book well worth reading because it weaves knowns in current neurological research with physics and discusses the implications of both these fields on our future as a society and a species.

The book is an interesting read for those who like psychology, neurology, and physics. I particularly enjoyed the chapter on consciousness as an energy state. The book seems to be directed to an audience that is more familiar with psychology, and less familiar with physics (as you might expect from a physics author who is able to write at length about physics principles, but is less familiar with psychology, or neuroscience). Nonetheless, I thoroughly enjoyed the book. I would have given it a full five stars had it not been for a few sections that felt repetitive, a few chapters that felt disjointed, and a few glaring grammatical errors. Overall, I would recommend the book to those whose leisure reading includes non-fiction.

While I cannot agree with his conclusions concerning Moore's law (due to his insistence of applying it to only one scientific discipline) the book is filled with good information.  Sadly, the professor does not explore the obvious implications of extending the Brain Computer Interface to an external memory and computational device accessible via miniature WiFi antenna, which of course could be installed on a chip.  Imagine a diplomat speaking any foreign language required ...fluently..simply by tapping into a translation device the size of a ring they wear.  Or learning to play piano like a concert master...by slipping on a watch.  The future of the mind extends beyond the limits of biology, and its only a matter of time.

After reading the first 110 pages I thought it was Michio Kaku's worst book but it gets incredibly good afterwards.  What a masterpiece!  The reason the beginning was bad is because it gives you a basic intro into how the brain works and being that I do research in this area, it was boring for me.  But this guy is a genius, the stuff you learn after the first 110 or 120 pages is incredible.  I can't believe that a theoretical physicist like Michio Kaku can create a book better than that of any neuroscience.  It's like a baseball player coming out and beating the heavy weight boxing champion of the world in his first fight.  Michio Kaku is the greatest ambassador or science or all time, hands down!

A grounded, accessible overview of neuroscience filled with exciting ideas about the near and long term potential of our minds. I found the back half of the book more interesting than the historical survey in the beginning. You'll learn an awful lot about how we'll be able to use our noggins in the future after reading this book. What I always appreciate about this Michio Kaku's work is that just about anyone can pick it up and understand what he's talking about, whereas others leave their readers behind in a maze of jargon. I also salute his appreciation of entrepreneurs and market forces first rather than being a government knows best guy.

Was introduced to the extraordinary Dr.Kaku on CBS MORNING. As a consultant he is often called upon to explain the events of earthquakes, threatening climate outcomes and such. He explains these principles with such clarity. When his latest book, "The Future of The Mind" was mentioned on the air, thought I'd try this one. Am only starting to get into it's reading, but I am most assuredly not at all disappointed. Only wish he had been around when I was dogging the taking of Physics. Maybe I would have pursued my first interest in the Sciences rather than Languages. Looking forward to reading some of Dr. Kaku's other works.

Michio Kaku is a theoretical physicist by profession, but has always been fascinated by the mysteries of the human mind.  He covers everything from telepathy, telekinesis, mind control attempts, artificial intelligence, etc.  I particularly enjoyed his way of referencing popular movies that delved into the many areas of the Mind.  Either confirming or denying their possibilities.  With detailed descriptions of the physical anatomy of the brain to the affects of mental illnesses or drugs, this is a fantastic book.  I recommend this to anyone who has any interest in how or why the mind reacts the way it does.

If there is a scientist: considering myself as one, who could do the mind justice; more appropriately than this writer:  I've not heard of them.  But this great writing is about more than that, because that subjects too small for this genius; Dr. Kaku doesn't stand alone in this field, rather he admits the giant shoulders that got him here...and that surround him, but don't let that scare you- we're fundamentally changing as Naisbitt and others, Toffler i.e., told us decades back; would take place- now this brilliant mechanic will help you use the right oil with your hybrid!  An amazing tool.

Although I have seen this author on TV and listened to him on the radio, this is my first book of his.  Not disappointed!  I read things with a little skepticism when I first begin.  I really gained credibility for the information with him listing the Acknowledgements- many pages- before the introduction. The first chapter offers illustrations & history to remind the reader of the brain, it's bits, and function translations. Less than 350 pages but packed with be unafraid of mind science. I am not in any science field, just interested in how the body's control center works and could evolve.

Although we are at the beginning, we're now just starting to be able to map the brain and understanding it. We have a very long way to go, but to our help we have technologies such as the mri-scan and many others that are getting cheaper, less intrusive, and more accurate at a exponential pace. I'm a fan of Michio Kaku and have red both Physics of the Future and Physics of the Impossible. Here he leaves his normal domain of Physics in order to meet with some of the greatest brain scientists. As in his other books, he explains complicated things in a entertaining and easy to understand way.

Dr. Kaku's writing is clear and concise.  It is also clear that he is on the cutting edge of science not only in the U.S. but the world. He has access to the world's top researchers.  He does an excellent job of differentiating between what is clearly possible and even probable in the future and what is merely speculative at this point in time.  In any case I found it to be entertaining and informative.  I would highly recommend it to anyone who wishes to have a peak into what the future holds for the human race.
I am glad to have read this book. What a visionary. can't get enough.

A must read for an futurist or person interested in the human mind.  Upon reading it I immediately sent it to a grandson who will enjoy the adventure outlined in the book.  Yes, it is a book for young people who are interested in science and how technology has advanced since WWII.  It is also a book for others who appreciate science and are fascinated by our brains.  We know so little, yet our brain controls us and the future of humanity.  Read it and pass it on.  More people should read this book.

I found much of the information presented in this book quite interesting.  Michio does his best to present ideas in a manner that many can relate to, often using movie and television references.  However, there is far too much repetition in this book.  I found myself skimming through sections because it was simply a re-introduction of ideas presented just pages before.  Overall I feel like this book could have, and should have, been half the length that it is had it been written more to-the-point.

In principle, it’s interesting to read it as sort of a fiction book because Mr. Kaku didn’t try to consider any factors which might influence science development and creation of new technologies, e.g. how our society will develop, how we exploit our environment, etc. Additionally, he repeats some things from his previous books and it’s really annoying.

Fascinating exploration of what the future may hold for study of the brain and a good recap of our five senses and how magical our bodies and minds are. Later chapters about ESP and aliens were rather lame and belonged in a different book, in my opinion, which is why he lost a star. I hope I'm around when science creates a computer that rivals the speed and efficiency of the human brain, and our technology advances to the point where such deadly diseases such as Alzheimer's may be eradicated.

The physicist, Michio Kaku’s The Future of the Mind may be the best book ever written about consciousness and the brain.  It is carefully researched.  It contains summaries of the experiments and speculations of a variety of scientists in a variety of disciplines.  It combines hard facts with possibilities.  For example, he details a lot of state of the art brain research and its conclusions.  But he also discusses what robotic and alien brains and consciousnesses might be like.

This is an overview of what Science knows and has concluded thus far about the mind. Perhaps it is more about the brain but the two words brain and mind are usually used interchangeably. This is a very interesting report on the development of science in its quest to understand the human mind. This could remove our massive ignorance about something which we are which is mind. It is good reading.

Michio Kaku has this way of bringing vast concepts and complex theories down to earth for the average curious person to understand.  Seeing the future possibility of currently developing science and technology, Kaku theorizes what society may do with these advances.  This book is perfect for exploring many different ideas relating to the mind through hard physical science and doing what conscious minds do best, trying to project into the future to see what comes next.

For once in his many writings - Michio Kaku has escaped his typical obfuscating style and written a focused foundation on how physics defines the functioning of the brain. Most of all he puts a great deal of perspective on how far scientist and the medical world have come in understanding the brain. It is written at a basic, not complicated level and is a very good reference to this strategic organ and how it will evolve.

Professor MIshio Kaku takes you thru the evolution of the physical development of the brain, points out all the functions of different parts relating to our thoughts,parts causing various mental problems and possible solutions. You will find his information comes from thorough research, consulting top minds in the field, including advances in machines tracking the brain as it works. Refreshing and well worth the read.

For a reader like me who's perpetually intrigued by neuroscience and cognitive science, this book proves to be a bona fide delight.  Unlike obscure textbooks, Kaku's book facilitates reading by constantly drawing up analogies to pop culture.  There are some grammatical errors, such as misplaced prepositions after preposition phrases.  So, Michio Kaku may need to read Steven Pinker's "The Sense of Style" :)

I think anything Kaku produces is of great benefit to us all. As a prophet of science and artist of imagination he has very few rivals intellectually. Future generations will appreciate his genius far more than its one and he is a historical figure beyond what people perceive him to be today. If we could all be so lucky to just have a faction of his insight the world would be a better place. Slade Grantham.

It was thought provoking book on the future of the mind.  I am a molecular biologist and was perturbed by the completely wrong description of the function of ribosome.  His information is based on interviews with experts(?) outside of his field, and there may be other things wrong with it, but I am provoked by the possibility  of the mind of the future.  I was motivated and led the discussions on the book.

Kaku breaks it down for the simple and unscientific but interesting geeks among us.  I have a much more appreciative view of SciFi geeks. What would it be like to achieve a Vulcan Mind Meld a la Mr. Spock? If there is anyone on the planet who could do that, my wish would be that Dr. Michio Kaku be that person. How I would love to know what he knows! Talk about a transcendant experience! Unfortunately, science isn't quite there. Yet. But that hasn't stopped Dr.Kaku from taking us "one step beyond" in his exploration of what the present state of physics suggests might be possible in the not too distant future. If you have a literal mind, this is not a book for you. Dr. Kaku's speciality is theoretical physics not material science so he does what theorists are supposed to do: extrapolate from what we know and have the equipment to measure or observe right now to the furthest edge of possibility. It can be argued that we are only in the very early stages of "brain science" but the rate of discovery in the field is progressing exponentially. Almost daily researchers publish new - and often unexpected - findings on how the physical brain functions. We are beginning to be able to see the path of a thought as it travels the neuro-circuits of the physical brain. But thought itself cannot be seen, weighed, or measured in any way. It is invisible and leaves only the faintest temporary imprint for us to observe. Dr. Kaku wrestles with the problem of consciousness in his quest to understand the MIND. Our minds use our brains to record and communicate thought. But is Mind identical with Brain? This is the question that must ultimately be asked and answered. What IS consciousness and where does it come from? Is it dependent on the brain or does it exist in the quantum universe and express itself through conscious creatures in the form of thought? And, if so, does that mean that pure consciousness really does exist and that it has intention and will? Dr. Kaku is one of our planet's most enquiring minds and he'd like to know. So would I. I think I'll stick around and wait to see what he does next.

An amazing look at the brain and how it works from the view of a physicist. I was disappointed that Kaku didn't narrate the entire book, but the narration was well done.
